custom_fields.key_topics:
You will apply the tools you learn in class to analyze different fixed-income, equity, and derivative securities and portfolios. At the end of the course, you should be to:
o Describe the theoretical and the empirical risk and reward characteristics for several asset classes including equities, treasury bonds, corporate bonds, and derivative securities such as options, futures contracts, and forward contracts.
o Calculate the term structure of interest rates, price coupon bonds and interest rates swaps, and apply fixed-income risk measurement and risk management tools including duration and convexity to these instruments.
o Use portfolio optimization techniques to design and implement efficiently diversified investment strategies.
o Use arbitrage techniques to hedge and value derivative securities including options contracts, forward contracts, futures contracts, swaps, and fixed-income securities.
o Design hedging strategies involving options, futures, forwards, swaps and other derivative securities.
o Use models such as the CAPM and factor pricing models to evaluate various portfolios and to evaluate portfolio managers and their strategies.
o Apply derivative pricing techniques to value equities, bonds with credit risk, and other corporate securities with embedded options.
custom_fields.prerequisite_knowledge: In addition to the course prerequisites, you should be familiar with Excel, basic statistics, and economic concepts.
custom_fields.assessment_structure: The course grade will be based on several problem sets, a midterm, and final example and a group investment project.

custom_fields.relevance: IA is the core markets course in finance. We examine issues of how asset prices are formed and how to form and evaluate investment strategies using financial securities. The topics are valuable in many areas in finance, including sales and trading, corporate treasuries and investment banking.
custom_fields.learning_resources: Course slides and notes, problem sets and solved problems will be available on Canvas. There will be a TA and the course will have a Piazza site.
custom_fields.extra_time_commitment: Homeworks; a group project for which student teams meet outside of class; TA office hours

long_desc: Investment analysis provides you the concepts and tools used to analyze publicly traded securities, and you will learn how to these tools to real world situations. The course is organized as a tour of the different kinds of securities used in the financial markets. You will analyze how security prices are determined, the relations between the prices of different securities, their risks and returns, and how to choose a portfolio or strategy from different asset classes. This course may use thirdparty course material that is not available for individual purchase from the publisher.   If so, the thirdparty course material will be secured and provided by the Tepper School to students enrolled in the course, and students enrolled in the course will be required to pay to the University the associated additional course materials fee for the thirdparty course material provided.   The amount of the course materials fee is dependent on the Universitys cost of the particular materials provided, and typically ranges from 13 to 75.
